title-group.article-title: A numerical analysis of large amplitude beam vibration under different boundary conditions and excitation patterns

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India

author-notes.corresp: Prasanta Sahoo, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700032, India Email: psjume@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Large amplitude forced vibration behavior of thin beams under harmonic excitation is studied, incorporating the effect of geometric nonlinearity. Large amplitude free vibration analysis of the same system is also carried out to obtain the backbone curves. When a very small loading is considered, the system response becomes almost identical to the backbone curve, which confirms the validity of the large amplitude study. The sets of governing equations for both forced and free vibration problems are obtained using Hamilton’s principle, whereas the same for the static problem are obtained by applying the variational form of the energy principle. The solution of the static problem provides system stiffness as a function of deflection and it becomes an input to the corresponding free vibration problem. The results are presented in the nondimensional frequency–amplitude plane in the form of response curves, and the related backbone curves are shown to represent the complete system behavior. Results for different combinations of classical flexural boundary conditions and loading patterns are reported.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Beams used in various mechanical structures are often subjected to time varying forces. Whenever such a beam exhibits large amplitude motion, the analysis no longer remains linear and, therefore, nonlinear analysis is performed to investigate its dynamic behavior. The analysis for investigating the large amplitude dynamic response of beams has significant contribution in engineering design. A brief account of the literatures available in this domain is given below.

Marur (2001) carried out an extensive review work on nonlinear beam vibration formulations. Lau and Cheung (1981) used the amplitude incremental variational principle to study periodic nonlinear vibrations of elastic systems. Bennett and Eisley (1970) studied the nonlinear free and forced response of clamped beams under concentrated harmonic force using a multimode approach. Mei and Decha-Umpkai (1985) used the finite element method for nonlinear forced vibration analysis of beam structures subjected to harmonic excitation. The statistical properties of a geometrically nonlinear mode spectrum for large amplitude forced vibration systems had been estimated by Ma et al. (1995a) using the finite element method. Ma et al. (1995b) used the matrix perturbation method for the large amplitude forced vibration analysis of beams, incorporating longitudinal inertia in the formulation. Adam (1999) obtained solution of the initial boundary value problem of coupled bending-torsional vibrations of elastic monosymmetric beams.

Azrar et al. (1999, 2002) employed the single mode and multi-mode semi-analytical approach to the nonlinear dynamic response problem of clamped and simply supported beams. Hsueh (1999) obtained analytical and closed-form frequency responses for the longitudinal vibration of multi-stepped rods with or without lumped elements, having nonclassical boundary conditions. The bending–bending forced vibration behavior of pretwisted nonuniform Timoshenko beams was studied by Lin and Lee (2002), using Hamilton's principle. Using the shooting method, the geometric nonlinear large amplitude forced vibration of thin/thick beams was studied by Ribeiro (2004), based on p-version hierarchical finite element formulation.

Wu (2005) obtained closed-form solutions for the forced vibrations of a rod and beam excited by displacement boundary conditions. Somnay and Ibrahim (2006) studied the nonlinear dynamics associated with the large deformation of a beam sliding on two knife edge supports under external excitation. Daqaq et al. (2008) investigated the effect of feedback delays on the nonlinear vibration of a piezo-electrically actuated cantilever beam. Mikata (2008), by treating the orthogonality condition for a multi-span beam, carried out the transient forced vibration analysis of a two-span Euler–Bernoulli beam.

Zhang et al. (2008) investigated the forced transverse vibration behavior of an elastically connected simply supported Bernoulli–Euler double-beam system under compressive axial load. Çalım (2009) studied the free and forced vibration behavior of nonuniform composite Timoshenko beams, taking the effects of shear deformation and rotary inertia in the formulation. Machado and Cortínez (2009) investigated the dynamic stability of thin-walled composite beams subjected to transverse external force using a seven-degrees-of-freedom shear-deformable beam theory.

The present paper deals with the large amplitude forced vibration analysis of thin beams. The related free vibration analysis of the same system is also presented for completeness of the study. To capture large amplitude dynamic behavior, the geometric nonlinearity of the system is considered in the mathematical formulation. It is known that, in the case of geometric nonlinearity, the stiffness of the system becomes a function of the solution parameters, which are not known a priori. This gives rise to set of nonlinear governing equations. The solution is obtained through an iterative method and the results are presented in the form of frequency response curves in the nondimensional plane. Validation of the present method is successfully carried out with the available results in the literature. Results are furnished for different combinations of boundary conditions of the beam and types of loading pattern.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical formulation
sec.p: In the present study, both forced and related free vibration analyses of beams under large amplitude oscillations are carried out numerically. In forced vibration analysis, the system response is shown in the displacement amplitude versus frequency of the external harmonic excitation plane, while the amplitude of external excitation is kept fixed. This family of curves for different excitation values indicates the functional relationship of the maximum displacement of the beam with the frequency of excitation and is known as the frequency response of the beam. It is to be mentioned that only the steady-state dynamic response of the beam under harmonic transverse loading is considered for the present study. The mathematical formulation is energy based, and the set of governing equations is derived using Hamilton’s principle. For the free vibration analysis, a large displacement is statically imposed first by applying transverse loading on the beam, and then the dynamic problem is formulated as an eigenvalue analysis by applying Hamilton’s principle, using the system stiffness corresponding to a large static displacement field.

The solution is approximate in nature, due to the assumption of the individual displacement fields as finite linear combinations of orthogonal admissible functions and unknown coefficients. The set of nonlinear equations obtained for the free vibration problem is solved by applying the direct substitution technique with a successive relaxation scheme. However, for forced vibration analysis, a globally convergent solution algorithm, known as Broyden’s method, is employed as it is found to be successful over a wide domain of system parameters.

The Typical frequency response curve of a beam under large amplitude forced vibration has different identifiable zones. A typical frequency response curve for undamped forced vibration is shown in Figure 1 forthe hardening-type nonlinearity. However, not all of the zones are physically obtainable because some of them are not stable. The response curve is called the backbone curve if the amplitude of external excitation is zero, and it is obtained through free vibration analysis, performed under different static load levels. The response curves for three different harmonic load amplitudes are shown along with the backbone curve. Figure 1.
Typical frequency response curve.

For each response curve, three zones are obtained, namely zone A, zone B and zone C. Zones A and B are the stable zones, whereas zone C is unstable in nature and as such cannot be obtained by experimental investigation. It is clear that for small excitation frequency, there is a unique response of the system, and the response points for this case constitute zone A. However, above a certain excitation frequency, the system mathematically provides three response amplitudes, one of them obviously being in zone A, and the other two constitute two distinct response zones, namely zone B and zone C. Mathematically it can be shown that zones B and C signify out-of-phase motion against the in-phase motion of zone A. It should be noted that zones A and B are the stable zones as they are experimentally obtainable, whereas zone C is unstable in nature. There is a frequency zone for which both zone A and zone B exist. In that particular frequency range, zone A can only be captured if the frequency is swept in an ascending manner, whereas to reach out in zone B in that frequency range, the frequency sweep should be done in a descending manner. It is to be noted that P¯1, P¯2 and P¯3 represent three different harmonic load amplitudes, in ascending order.

The mathematical formulation is based on the assumption that the beam material is isotropic and homogeneous, and follows linear elastic material behavior. The beam under consideration is of length L with uniform rectangular cross section (bxt), where b and t are the width and thickness, respectively. The beam has very little thickness compared to its length. Hence, the effect of shear deformation is neglected during imposing a large amplitude for free vibration analysis, and the effect of rotary inertia is neglected during dynamic analysis.

The present formulation is generalized in nature to analyze problems for any classical flexural boundary conditions and loading patterns. Four well-known classical boundary conditions of beams, namely clamped–clamped (CC), simply supported–simply supported (SS), clamped–simply supported (CS) and clamped–free (CF), are considered for generating results. For each of these boundary conditions, four different types of loadings, namely concentrated load at the midpoint (at the tip for a CF beam), uniformly distributed load (Udl), triangular load and hat-type load, are considered. Figure 2 and 3 present schematic diagrams of different boundary conditions and loading patterns, respectively. The nomenclatures related to the loading patterns are discussed in the next section. Figure 2.
Different boundary conditions: (a) clamped–clamped (CC); (b) simply supported–simply supported (SS); (c) clamped–simply supported (CS); (d) clamped–free (CF). Figure 3.
Different loading patterns: (a) concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed; (c) triangular; (d) hat.

sec.title: 2.1. Forced vibration analysis
sec.p: In the present study, the forced vibration analysis is carried out in an indirect way. The external excitation is considered as harmonic, and the system response is assumed to have the same frequency as that of the external excitation. For a particular load level of the external excitation, a frequency sweep is carried out. Corresponding to each frequency of that particular load level, the dynamic system is made to maintain the force equilibrium at the peak load level. Thus the dynamic problem is solved as a static one and, quite obviously, the response of the static system becomes a function of the external excitation frequency and amplitude of loading.

Four different loading patterns have been considered as shown in Figure 3, where P and p represent harmonic excitation for concentrated (Figure 3(a)) and pressure-type loadings (Figures 3(b)–(d)), respectively. xp is the axial coordinate of the point of application of concentrated loading, which is 0.5L for CC, SS and CS boundary conditions and L for the CF boundary condition. Besides concentrated load, the other three types of pressure loadings are termed as uniform, triangular and hat loadings. The expressions of harmonic excitation are given by (1a)P=P¯exp(iθτ),forconcentratedloading (1b)p=p¯(x)exp(iθτ),forpressure-typeloading where i=-1 and θ denotes the frequency of excitation, P¯ represents the amplitude for concentrated loading and p¯ represents the intensity of harmonic excitation per unit length of the beam for pressure-type loading. It is to be mentioned that p¯max is the amplitude of maximum intensity for triangular and hat-type loadings (Figures 3(c) and (d)).

For the present study, a large displacement analysis of beam is considered in which both bending and stretching of the neutral plane is accounted. The bending action is caused by the transverse load and contributes to the transverse displacement w, whereas the stretching displacement u is caused by in-plane restraints to the displacement. It is to be mentioned that both w and u are referred to at the neutral plane of the beam.

The set of governing equations for the dynamic system is obtained by applying Hamilton’s principle, which is given by (2)δ(∫τ1τ2ζdτ)=0 where the Lagrangian ζ(=T-(U+V)) consists of three energy functionals, kinetic energy T, strain energy U and work potential V. In the said equation, τ denotes time and δ is the variational operator. The energy functionals are determined from the assumed dynamic displacement fields of w and u. As the frequency of response is considered identical with the excitation frequency, determination of T becomes straightforward. The expression of kinetic energy is given by (3)T=12ρbt∫0L{(∂w∂τ)2+(∂u∂τ)2}dx where ρ is the density of the beam material.
The work functional is computed corresponding to peak load level. The work potential V of external loading is given by (4)V=-P w|xp-∫0Lpwdx

The expression of strain energy is given by (5)U=Eb2∫-t/2t/2∫0L(ɛx b+ɛx s)2dxdy where the axial strain of a fiber at a distance y from the neutral plane due to bending action is given by ɛx b=-y∂2w∂x2. The axial strain due to stretching of the neutral plane is given by ɛx s=∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2.

Using the expressions of bending and stretching parts of axial strains, the expression of strain energy takes the following form: (6)U=EI2∫0L(∂2w∂x2)2dx+EA2∫0L{(∂u∂x)2+14(∂w∂x)4+∂u∂x(∂w∂x)2}dx where E is Young’s modulus of the beam material, and I and A are the second moment of the area and the area of the beam cross section, respectively. In arriving at Equation (6), the following properties of a rectangular beam cross section about the neutral axis have been considered: b∫-t/2t/2dy=A,b∫-t/2t/2ydy=0andb∫-t/2t/2y2dy=I

The dynamic displacements are taken to be separable in space and time, as shown below: (7a)w(x,τ)=wx(x)exp(iθτ) (7b)u(x,τ)=ux(x)exp(iθτ) where θ is the response frequency as specified earlier and wx and ux are the spatial distributions of transverse and in-plane displacements, respectively.

Using the expressions given by (3), (4) and (6), and using the expressions of harmonic loadings given by (1) and dynamic displacements given by (7), the set of governing equations is obtained from Equation (2) as (8)EI∫0L(d2wxdx2)δ(d2wxdx2)dx +EA∫0L{(duxdx)δ(duxdx)+12(dwxdx)3δ(dwxdx) +12(dwxdx)2δ(duxdx)+(duxdx)(dwxdx)δ(dwxdx)}dx -θ2ρbt∫0L{(dwxdτ)δ(dwxdτ)+(duxdτ)δ(duxdτ)} dx=P¯δ( wx|xp)+∫0Lp¯(x)δ(wx)dx

Using the expressions of approximate displacement fields given by (9), the set of governing equations is obtained from Equation (8) as (10)[K]{c}-θ2[M]{c}={f} where {c} is the vector of unknown coefficients and [K], [M] and {f} are the stiffness matrix, mass matrix and load vector, respectively, which are of the form given below: [K]=[[k11][k12][k21][k22]],[M]=[[M11][M12][M21][M22]]and{f}={f11f12}T

The elements of [K], [M] and {f} are given below: [k11]=EIL3∑j=1 nw∑i=1 nw∫01d2φidξ2d2φjdξ2dξ+EA2L3∑j=1 nw∑i=1 nw∫01(∑i=1 nwcidφidξ)2dφidξdφjdξdξ+EAL2∑j=1 nw∑i=1 nw∫01(∑i=nw+1 nw+nucidαi-nwdξ)dφidξdφjdξdξ [k12]=0 [k21]=EA2L2∑j=nw+1 nw+nu∑i=1 nw∫01(∑i=1 nwcidφidξ)dφidξdαj-nwdξdξ [k22]=EAL∑j=nw+1 nw+nu∑i=nw+1 nw+nu∫01dαi-nwdξdαj-nwdξdξ [M11]=ρLbt∑j=1 nw∑i=1 nw∫01φiφjdξ [M12]=0 [M21]=0 [M22]=ρLbt∑j=nw+1 nw+nu∑i=nw+1 nw+nu∫01αi-nwαj-nwdξ {f11}=P¯∑j=1 nw φj|ξp+L∑j=1 nw∫01p¯(ξ)φj(ξ)dξ {f12}=0 Here, ξp is the normalized axial coordinate of the point of application of concentrated loadings, which is 0.5 for CC, SS and CS boundary conditions and 1.0 for the CF boundary condition. The set of governing equations is nonlinear in nature and its solution methodology is discussed in the next section. It must be mentioned that for triangular and hat-type loadings, the load distribution p¯(ξ) can be obtained by knowing the amplitude of maximum intensity of load, that is, p¯max.

sec.title: 2.1.1. Solution methodology for the forced vibration problem
sec.p: Equation (10) can be expressed as [[K]-θ2[M]]{c}={f}. Here, the load vector {f} contains the amplitude of loading (P¯ or p¯), and the forcing frequency θ appears explicitly in the equation. The solution of this equation requires a solver for a set of nonlinear equations, as the matrix [K] is nonlinear. For a specified magnitude of loading, the dynamic stiffness [[K]-θ2[M]] depends on the frequency of loading. In the present formulation, the system response is identified by the maximum deflection amplitude of the beam. The location of this maximum amplitude point is not known a priori, in general, due to the presence of asymmetric loading and boundary conditions. Hence this response point is identified by scanning over the entire solution field. It is also important to note that with increase in the frequency of excitation, the expression of [[K]-θ2[M]] may change its sign, and usually it occurs when θ > ω1, where ω1 is the first natural frequency of the beam. Under such a situation, there is a reversal of the phase of the system response and this is manifested as a sharp decline of deflection amplitude in the frequency response curve.

It is clear from Figure 1 that some part of the frequency response functions has multiple values for the same value of the excitation frequency. The aim of this study is to capture the stable zones A and B, while it is known that there is some portion of overlapping between them. Zone A is captured when frequency sweeps in an ascending manner, whereas zone B is captured when frequency sweeps in a descending manner. The solution of the set of nonlinear governing equations (Equation (10)) is obtained by using two different methods and both of them are initial guess value dependent. When the solution of Equation (10) is tried with the substitution technique using a successive relaxation scheme, it could not capture zone A completely. However, it was able to capture zone B almost completely, even when the frequency sweeps in an ascending manner. Although the method has limited applicability, it is computationally efficient and requires much less processing time.

To enhance the domain of applicability, a computationally stiff multidimensional secant method, known as Broyden’s algorithm, is employed as the second method for solving Equation (10), and it could capture both zones A and B completely. However, this method is strongly dependent on initial guess values. So, the first set of initial guess values during the solution in zone B is supplied by solving the same set of equations (Equation (10)) using the substitution technique with successive relaxation. It is to be mentioned that solution for zone B is obtained by sweeping the frequency from higher to lower values. The successive relaxation scheme is well known and details of Broyden’s algorithm are given by Press et al. (1992).

sec.title: 2.2. Free vibration analysis: determination of backbone curves
sec.p: The large amplitude free vibration analysis of the beam is carried out in two phases. A large amplitude is imposed to the beam through static loading (Saha et al., 2004; Das et al., 2008, 2010) and then its free vibration analysis is performed as an eigenvalue problem to identify the loaded natural frequency. The variation of the natural frequency with the maximum amplitude of deflection yields the backbone curve of the physical system, which is the plot of the nondimensional frequency–amplitude relationship. The beam has different backbone curves for different modes of vibration, but for the present case, only the first mode of vibration of the beam is considered.

The dynamic problem is formulated by applying Hamilton’s principle given by Equation (2), where T, U and V carry their usual meanings mentioned earlier, and their expressions remain the same as provided for the forced vibration analysis of beams. However, for the present problem of free vibration analysis of beams, the term V vanishes, while the expressions of T and U remain the same.

The dynamic displacements w(ξ,τ) and u(ξ,τ) are assumed to be a linear combination of space and time functions as shown below: (11a)w(ξ,τ)≅∑i=1 nwciφi(ξ)γi(τ) (11b)u(ξ,τ)≅∑i=nw+1 nw+nuciαi-nw(ξ)γi(τ) Here, all the terms carry their usual meanings and ci is a new set of unknown coefficients to be evaluated, which indicates the contribution of the individual shape functions in a particular vibration frequency mode. The set of admissible functions ϕi and αi are the same as used for the earlier forced vibration analysis and the set of temporal functions γi is expressed by γi=exp(iωτ), where ω represents the natural frequency of the beam.

After substituting the necessary expressions in Equation (2), the resulting solution is obtained as an eigenvalue problem, as follows: (12)-ω2[M]{c}+[K]{c}=0 Here, [K] and [M] are the stiffness matrix and mass matrix, respectively, forms and elements of which are identical to those used for the forced vibration problem. The effect of large amplitude on the free vibration behavior of the beam is taken into the formulation of the dynamic problem by using the solution parameters of the corresponding static problem (Saha et al., 2004; Das et al., 2008, 2010). It is to be mentioned that the static problem is formulated and solved for imposing large amplitude on the beam, a brief description of which is given in the next section. The nonlinear terms of the stiffness matrix for the eigenvalue problem are linearized using the solution of the static problem, and this incorporates the effect of large amplitude of vibration imposed statically. The eigenvalues are solved numerically by using International Mathematical and Statistical Library (IMSL) routines, and the square roots of these eigenvalues represent the large amplitudefree vibration frequencies of the beam. When these frequencies are plotted against the corresponding amplitudes, the backbone curve is obtained, as mentioned earlier.

sec.title: 2.2.1. Static problem
sec.p: The set of governing equations for the static problem is obtained using the variational principle, which is given by (13)δ(U+V)=0 where U is strain energy and V is potential energy of the external load. The expressions of V and U remain the same as those given by Equations (4) and (6), respectively, except the implicit fact that the loading being considered here, unlike that given by Equation (1), is static in nature.
The displacement fields for wx and ux (as the displacements become a function of the axial coordinate only) are assumed to be of the form given by Equation (9).

sec.title: 3. Results and discussion
sec.p: The results are presented as frequency response curves in the nondimensional frequency–amplitude plane in which the ordinate represents the normalized maximum amplitude of vibration, wmax (normalized by the thickness of the beam cross section), and the abscissa represents the normalized forcing frequency θ¯ (normalized by the first linear natural frequency, ω1). It should be noted that the value of ω1 is obtained from free vibration analysis of the beam. In the present study, four different flexural boundary conditions of the beam, namely CC, SS, CS and CF, have been considered, and for each of these boundary conditions, results are generated for four types of loadings, which are the concentrated, uniformly distributed, triangular and hat-type of load. These four boundary conditions are considered in the present study as they are the only physically realizable ones for a beam. As regard to the loading patterns considered in the present study, they encompass a wide variety of engineering applications. However, any other loading patterns, expressible by analytical or numerical functions, can be analyzed by using the present methodology.

sec.title: 3.1. Validation
sec.p:
The frequency response curves of the CC beam under concentrated harmonic excitation at midpoint are compared with the results presented by Ribeiro (2004). The comparison plots are generated for a 0.406 m long beam having 0.02 m × 0.002 m cross section with material properties E = 71.72 GPa and ρ = 2800 kg/m3. The comparison plots are shown in Figures 4(a) and (b) for excitation amplitudes P¯ = 0.134 N and P¯ = 2 N, respectively. These plots show fairly good agreement and establish the validity of the present method. Figure 4.
Validation plots for the frequency response curve of a clamped–clamped beam under a harmonic concentrated load acting at the midpoint: (a) P¯ = 0.134 N; (b) P¯ = 2 N.

In the present paper, both forced and free vibration behavior of beams are studied. The free vibration behavior of beams is presented in terms of backbone curves. Theoretically, the response curve of a beam under harmonic excitation should conform to its corresponding backbone curve, that is, with gradually diminishing load amplitudes, the resulting response curves should become asymptote to the corresponding backbone curve. The plots of this type are shown in Figures 5(a) and (b) for SS and CS beams, respectively, under a Udl. Each plot shows response curves for five different load amplitudes, contrasting them with the backbones curves. For each case, it is clear that the response curves, expectedly, become asymptote with the backbone curve, with a decrease in load amplitudes. This again validates the present mathematical model of forced and free vibration analysis with each other. Figure 5.
Comparison plots of frequency response curves for different load amplitudes with backbone curves under a uniformly distributed load: (a) simply supported–simply supported (SS) beam; (b) clamped–simply supported (CS) beam.

sec.title: 3.2. Response curves for different loading patterns and boundary conditions
sec.p:
Results are generated for a uniform beam with the following geometric and material parameter values: L = 1 m, b = 0.02 m, t = 0.01 m, E = 210 GPa and ρ = 7850 kg/m3. The response curves for the CC beam are presented in Figures 6(a)–(d) for four different types of load, and in each of these plots, response curves are presented for two different values of excitation amplitudes, the values of which are indicated in the legends of the corresponding figures. In addition, the corresponding backbone curves, that is, the zero amplitude excitation curves, obtained from free vibration analysis of the beam are furnished in each of these plots by solid continuous lines. Similar plots of response curves under different harmonic loading patterns for SS, CS and CF beams are shown in Figures 7–9, respectively. The corresponding backbone curves are also shown in each of these plots by solid continuous lines. It must be noted that the response curves are presented to capture the first mode of vibration. Zone A of the curve is presented up to the frequency at which normalized amplitude attains the value 2.0, whereas the response curves in zone B are generally presented up to the excitation frequency where the normalized amplitude is minimum. The typical jump phenomenon of nonlinear vibration is observed numerically at a limiting frequency value in zone B, below which the response curve switches to zone A. Figure 6.
Nondimensional frequency response curves of clamped–clamped beams under different types of loading: (a) concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed load (Udl); (c) triangular; (d) hat. Figure 7.
Nondimensional frequency response curves of simply supported–simply supported beams under different types of loading: (a) concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed load (Udl); (c) triangular; (d) hat. Figure 8.
Nondimensional frequency response curves of clamped–simply supported beams under different types of loading: (a)concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed load (Udl); (c) triangular; (d) hat. Figure 9.
Nondimensional frequency response curves of clamped–free beams under different types of loading: (a) concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed load (Udl); (c) triangular; (d) hat.

The response curves clearly show two distinct zones, A and B. The unstable zone C of a typical frequency curve (as shown in Figure 1) did not yield any solution, as expected. For each of the response curves, the static response is indicated by the point at which the response curve initiates from the vertical axis, that is, corresponding to zero excitation frequency. The nature of the plots of backbone curves shows the hardening-type nonlinearity of the beams. It can be seen that for a particular excitation frequency, the response amplitude increases with increase in excitation amplitude, and this is valid for both zones A and B. It is also observed that, for zone A, the frequency response increases with increase in excitation frequency, whereas for zone B, the frequency response decreases with increase in excitation frequency. This indicates that the motion of the beam in zone A and zone B are out-of-phase, and this observation is consistent for all the results presented.

Comparing the response curves for all the boundary conditions, it is clear that SS beams provide a flatter zone A compared to the other types of boundary conditions, among which the CC beam provides the steepest response curve in zone A. For CC and SS beams, triangular harmonic loading provides a very narrow zone B compared to the other three types of loadings. However, for CS beams, almost all the loadings provide a very narrow zone B. On the other hand, CF beams have a wide zone B for all four types of loadings. In order to make these comparisons clearer, a separate study has been done to show the effect of boundary conditions on frequency response curves and this is provided in Section 3.3.

sec.title: 3.3. Effect of boundary conditions
sec.p:
The spectra over which the stable zones of the frequency response curve extend are very important for design engineers, in order to avoid the resonance phenomenon. From the observations presented in the preceding section, it is quite clear that the nature of nondimensional response curves vary widely for different boundary conditions. For that purpose, Figures 10(a) and (b) are presented to show the effect of four different boundary conditions for concentrated and uniformly distributed loadings, respectively, in the nondimensional frequency–amplitude plane. The basis of comparison for each type of loading is that the beams for four different boundary conditions have the same normalized maximum static deflection. The normalized maximum static deflection is taken as 0.6 for each case and the load amplitudes for attaining these deflection amplitudes are mentioned in the legends of each figure. Figure 10 shows that the response curve in zone A is the steepest for the CC beam and it decreases gradually for CS, CF and SS boundary conditions. It is also clear from Figure 10 that the response curve in zone B starts with the SS beam and curves for CC, CF and CS beams come one after another. Figure 10.
Nondimensional frequency response curves of the same normalized maximum static deflection of different boundary conditions for two types of loading: (a) concentrated; (b) uniformly distributed load (Udl).

sec.title: 3.4. Deformed beam shape plots
sec.p:
Plots showing the deformed beam shape carry qualitative information regarding the boundary condition, loading and phase of motion of the beam. The deformed beam shapes are considered for two cases. One is the CC beam with hat loading having p¯max = 2000 N/m, and the other one is the CS beam with uniformly distributed loading having p¯ = 1000 N/m. For the first case, deformed beam shapes at various representative points on the response curve, as shown in Figure 11(a), are presented in Figure 11(b). Similar plots for the second case are shown in Figures 12(a) and (b). It is to be noted that the plots are furnished corresponding to the maximum dynamic displacement. Figure 11.
Deformed shape plots for a clamped–clamped beam with hat loading having p¯max = 2000 N/m: (a) response curve showing the representative points; (b) deformed shapes for the representative points. Figure 12.
Deformed shape plots for a clamped–simply supported beam with uniformly distributed loading having p¯ = 1000 N/m: (a) response curve showing representative points; (b) deformed shapes for the representative points.

The points on the response curves corresponding to different normalized frequency–amplitude combinations, at which the deformed shapes are furnished, are marked as M-R. Point M represents the case of static deflection of the beam when the excitation frequency is zero. Point N represents the case when the beam attains the maximum response amplitude considered for the present case, and point O corresponds to the case at the same frequency as that of point N but in zone B. The left-most point in zone B of the response curve is represented by point P. Point Q is obtained in zone A by moving vertically from point P, that is, both points P and Q correspond to the same excitation frequency. On the other hand, point R in zone A is reached when it is moved horizontally from point P, that is, both these points represent the same response amplitude.

Figure 11(b) shows that maximum dynamic displacement is attained at the midpoint of the beam irrespective of the excitation frequency, which is expected due to the symmetric nature of the loading pattern and boundary condition. The representative points in zone A clearly show that with increase in excitation frequency, the system response increases, and they are always in phase so long as they lie in zone A. Expectedly, all the points in zone B are out-of-phase and due to this, the response amplitude increases when the excitation frequency is decreased. The general observations for Figure 12(b) are the same as those obtained for Figure 11(a), except that the point of maximum displacement amplitude shifts from the midpoint towards the simply supported end, even if the loading is symmetric with respect to the midpoint. This is quite obvious, as the boundary condition is asymmetric in this case.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: Large amplitude forced vibrations of thin beams are presented in this paper, where the entire analysis is carried out numerically. The related free vibration behavior of the beam is also investigated for completeness of the study. Hamilton’s principle is employed for obtaining governing equations. The results are presented in the nondimensional frequency–amplitude plane in the form of frequency response curves. Validation is carried out successfully with the available results in the literature. Response curves for different combinations of flexural boundary conditions and loading patterns are presented. The pattern of the generated response curves matches well with the typical one for the hardening-type nonlinearity. Deformed beam shape plots are furnished to show the effect of the excitation frequency, boundary condition and loading pattern. The present study is carried out for the first vibration mode and a further study can be taken up to see the forced vibration behavior of the second mode.

The proposed methodology is general in nature, such that it can be used for any arbitrary loading patterns and for any classical boundary conditions. The developed solution algorithm is quite stable to capture the stable zones of the frequency response curves. The present work successfully uses Broyden’s algorithm to solve the nonlinear equations, giving stable solutions of the problem.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
